metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of S. N. Bhatnagar v. Respondents

facts.text: One S. N. Bhatnagar was the tenant of a building in a slum area in Delhi under the respondents.
On December 5, 1960, the respondents obtained a decree for eviction of the tenant, allowing time to vacate till March 2, 1963.

On June 19, 1964, the respondents obtained permission for execution of the decree from the competent authority under s. 19 of the Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 (as it stood before December 21, 1964).
On or about July 22, 1964, the respondents applied for execution of the decree.
The tenant filed objections to the execution application, which were dismissed on August 7, 1964.
An appeal against the order dated August 7, 1964 was dismissed on March 19, 1965.
Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Amendment Act, 1964 (Act No. XLIII of 1964) came into force on December 21, 1964, substituting new section 19 for the principal Act.
During pendency of appeal from August 7, 1964 order, the July 22, 1964 execution application was consigned to record room.

On March 23, 1965, respondents filed another application for execution to revive the substantive application filed on July 22, 1964, regarded as continuation of execution proceeding commenced on July 22, 1964.
Tenant filed fresh objections contending respondents not entitled to execute decree without fresh permission under new s. 19; objections dismissed by executing court on April 27, 1965.
Order dated April 27, 1965 confirmed by appellate court on June 9, 1965.
Revision petition to Punjab High Court at Delhi (Civil Revision No. 393-D of 1965) dismissed on December 15, 1965.
During pendency of revision petition, tenant died and appellants brought on record as legal representatives.
Appellants filed appeal by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the execution application filed on July 22, 1964 (with permission under old s.19) is rendered incompetent by absence of fresh permission under new s.19 inserted by Amending Act, 1964, or whether pending execution proceedings are governed by law at time of commencement.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents were not entitled to execute the decree without obtaining fresh permission from competent authority under new s.19 inserted by Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Amendment Act, 1964.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: New s.19(1)(b) of Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 as substituted by Amendment Act, 1964

respondent_arguments.text: Execution application filed July 22, 1964 with permission under old s.19 is competent; new s.19 does not affect pending execution proceedings expressly or by necessary implication.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Old s.19 of Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956; law in force at commencement of proceeding

court_reasoning.text: New s.19(1)(a) has no application as suit and decree obtained before commencement of Amending Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-s. (1)(b) bars execution of pre-commencement decrees without permission, but pending proceedings governed by law at commencement unless expressly or by necessary implication affected.

court_reasoning.text: Application for execution filed July 22, 1964 before Amending Act was competent under then law; new s.19 does not provide for stay or vary rights in pending proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Holding otherwise could leave decree-holder without remedy if fresh execution barred by limitation; legislature could not have intended such result.

court_reasoning.text: Rights in pending application decided by law as on July 22, 1964; application competent, objections rightly dismissed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: March 23, 1965 application is continuation of July 22, 1964 proceeding.

holdings.text: Newly inserted s.19 does not affect pending execution proceeding expressly or by necessary implication; rights decided by law at time proceeding commenced (July 22, 1964); execution competent without fresh permission.

statutes_cited.name: Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission obtained under old s.19 for execution; governed proceedings commenced before amendment

statutes_cited.name: Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Amendment Act, 1964 (Act No. XLIII of 1964)
statutes_cited.relevance: New s.19 bars execution of pre-commencement decrees without permission but does not affect pending proceedings; competent authority to consider specific factors in granting/refusing permission

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave against High Court order dismissing revision is dismissed; execution proceedings upheld as competent under law prevailing on July 22, 1964.

key_quotes.text: "Unless the Amending Act affects the pending execution proceeding by express words or by necessary implication, the rights of the parties in the pending proceeding must be decided according to the law in force at the time when the proceeding was commenced"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle applied to hold pending execution unaffected by new s.19

key_quotes.text: "The legislature could not have intended such a result" (referring to decree-holder left without remedy due to limitation).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects interpretation requiring fresh permission for pending cases
